words.definition: Arranged alphabetically; rudimentary.
examples: The abecedarian organization made finding entries easy.

words.definition: A faint sketch or representation; a foreshadowing.
examples: The preface gave an adumbration of the argument.
Early symptoms were an adumbration of disease.

words.definition: A concise saying or maxim; an aphorism.
examples: The teacher shared an apothegm daily.

words.definition: Indigenous; formed or originating in the place found.
examples: These plants are autochthonous to the region.

words.definition: Relating to mechanical arts; mundane.
examples: The banausic details bored the theorist.
He dismissed it as banausic work.

words.definition: Construction from whatever is available; eclecticism.
examples: The theory was a bricolage of different ideas.
Her art was a bricolage of found objects.

words.definition: The use of clever but unsound reasoning; sophistry.
examples: The lawyer's casuistry convinced no one.

words.definition: Relating to belief in a future thousand-year age of blessedness.
The study of duty and moral obligation.
examples: Kantian ethics is a form of deontology.

words.definition: A narrative or plot; the telling of a story.
examples: The film's diegesis spans several decades.
Music within the diegesis is heard by characters.

words.definition: Relating to extraordinarily detailed mental imagery.
examples: She had an eidetic memory for faces.
Eidetic imagery is rare in adults.

words.definition: Critical explanation or interpretation of a text.
The doctrine that knowledge depends on faith or revelation.
A state ruled by old people.
The founder or leader of a heretical movement.
The art of preaching or writing sermons.
Relating to illness caused by medical treatment.
Existing within; inherent.
examples: Some believe God is immanent in nature.
The danger was immanent in the situation.

words.definition: Too great to be expressed in words; indescribable.
Occupying a position at both sides of a boundary.
examples: The ritual created a liminal space.

words.definition: Relating to the Socratic method of eliciting knowledge.
Relating to mental activity or the intellect.
A person who gives help or comfort; advocate.
examples: The Holy Spirit is called the Paraclete.

words.definition: The vital spirit, soul, or creative force.
examples: The pneuma animates all living things.

words.definition: Practice as distinguished from theory; accepted practice.
examples: The praxis of teaching varies widely.

words.definition: The state of being close in space or relationship; proximity.
examples: The propinquity of the buildings was concerning.

words.definition: The use of fallacious arguments with intent to deceive.
Below the threshold of conscious perception.
The saying of the same thing twice in different words.
examples: His speech was full of tautologies.

words.definition: The defining spirit or mood of a particular period.
examples: The zeitgeist of the 1960s was revolutionary.
